body.p: I’m tired of hearing esteemed scientists referred to as “rat doctors.”

Such a statement is disrespectful to the investigator, represents ignorance on the part of the speaker, and trivializes the advances made with laboratory animals. The British Royal Society claims that every medical achievement in the last century was dependent in some way upon animal research.1 However, we don’t need to fall back on advances with antibiotics or insulin to underscore this point because discovery of fundamental nutrition knowledge has relied heavily on animal research. Indeed, the use of animal-model bioassays with defined purified diets allowed for quick progress defining food and/or specific nutrients associated with several diseases originally attributed to infectious origin (Table 1).2

caption.p: Animal Models Instrumental in Solving Various Nutrient Deficiency Diseases

body.p: An issue underappreciated by those not involved in biomedical animal research relates to the proper selection of the specific animal model to be utilized. Much like the varied range of animals listed in Table 1, certain animal models are superior to others based on the clinical condition and nutrient under study. Much progress has been made regarding intestinal adaptation in the adult rodent model of short bowel syndrome; however, the relevance of this work to pediatric short bowel syndrome is limited due to a large expansion of intestinal surface area in the neonatal versus that of an adult intestine. Does this developmental increase in intestine enhance the drivers for resection-induced adaptation in the neonate, or does it preclude any further growth beyond that occurring for intestinal development? It’s hard to know when using an adult rodent model. Further, preclinical models should ideally express the clinical symptoms associated with the diagnosis under study. Extensive intestinal resection in adult rats does not typically recapitulate the clinical symptoms associated with intestinal failure, such as malabsorption, dehydration, electrolyte deficiencies, diarrhea and progressive malabsorption. With such limitations in mind, biomedical scientists must carefully choose their experimental model based on the nutrient absorption, metabolism, and partitioning associated with the hypotheses to be tested.

In this issue of JPEN, Dr. Brunton and colleagues use a parenterally fed neonatal piglet with short bowel syndrome as a preclinical model to explore the role of early enteral nutrients on intestinal adaptation in infants with intestinal failure. These authors simulate the clinical management of these patients through use of combined parenteral and enteral nutrients, in an animal model known to exhibit the full clinical spectrum of intestinal failure that is observed in human neonates.3 The data reported certainly underscore the importance of early enteral nutrients in the postsurgical period to enhance intestinal adaptation. This knowledge would not be so clearly delineated without the proper use of animal models and certainly impacts patient care in the coming years.

Regardless of one’s opinion regarding animal experimentation, the benefits obtained for human health and disease are hard to refute. With that said, it is imperative that such work be done with the highest respect for the subjects and consideration regarding the optimal species and model needed. Organizations around the globe have endorsed the principles of the “3 Rs” when justifying the use of animals in research. These “3Rs” dictate that every effort must be made to:

list-item.p: replace the use of live animals by nonanimal alternatives;
reduce the number of animals used in research to the minimum required for meaningful results, and;
refine the procedures so that the degree of suffering is kept to a minimum.

body.p: I propose that an addition “R” to consider is relevance. As nutrition researchers, we are making progress on this front also and such approaches will certainly lead to more fundamental advances in the coming century.
And may we never forget respect.
